definitions: become fully aware or conscious of something as fact or truth
cause something to actually happen or become real through action
convert property or investments into actual money through sale
examples: She suddenly realised her mistake during the meeting
They didn't realise the danger until it was too late
The architect realised her vision through careful planning
We need to realise our goals through hard work
He realised his assets to pay off the debts
The company realised substantial profits from the sale

definitions: become fully aware or conscious of something as fact or truth
cause something to actually happen or become real through action
convert property or investments into actual money through sale
examples: She suddenly realized her mistake during the meeting
They didn't realize the danger until it was too late
The architect realized her vision through careful planning
We need to realize our goals through hard work
He realized his assets to pay off the debts
The company realized substantial profits from the sale

definitions: enlarge or shape a hole using a rotating cutting tool
criticize or reprimand someone severely and at length
examples: The mechanic reamed the cylinder to precise specifications
You need to ream the hole before inserting the bolt
The coach reamed the team for their poor performance
His boss reamed him out for missing the deadline

definitions: cut and gather crops or harvest from fields when mature
receive something as a consequence of previous actions or efforts
examples: Farmers reap wheat in late summer each year
They reaped the corn before the storm arrived
You will reap what you sow in life
The company reaped huge profits from the investment

definitions: come into sight or become visible again after being absent
examples: The sun reappeared after the clouds passed by
The missing cat reappeared after three days away
The symptoms may reappear if you stop taking medication
Old problems tend to reappear during stressful times

definitions: bring up and care for children until they are fully grown
rise up on the hind legs or lift oneself upward
examples: They reared three children in a small farmhouse
She was reared by her grandparents after her parents died
The horse reared when it saw the snake
The mountain reared up before them in the distance

definitions: change the position order or layout of things to a new arrangement
examples: She rearranged the furniture to create more space
We need to rearrange our schedule for next week
Can you rearrange these paragraphs for better flow?
They rearranged the seating chart before the wedding

definitions: think understand and form judgments using logical processes
present arguments to persuade someone through logical discussion
examples: Children learn to reason at different developmental stages
Scientists reason from evidence to reach conclusions
She reasoned with him to change his mind
You can't reason with someone who won't listen

definitions: put the parts of something back together after taking apart
come together again as a group after being dispersed
examples: The mechanic reassembled the engine after the repair
Can you reassemble this toy after cleaning it?
The class will reassemble after the lunch break
The committee reassembled to discuss the new proposal

definitions: state or express something again with confidence and force
examples: The president reasserted his commitment to the policy
She reasserted her authority after the challenge
The company needs to reassert its market position
He reasserted control over the rebellious department

definitions: consider or examine something again to form a new judgment
examples: The doctor reassessed the patient's condition after treatment
We need to reassess our strategy given new information
The committee will reassess all applications next month
Property values are reassessed every three years

definitions: allocate someone or something to a different task position or location
examples: The manager reassigned him to the marketing department
Teachers were reassigned to different schools this year
The project was reassigned to a more experienced team
Resources were reassigned to meet urgent priorities

definitions: say or do something to remove someone's doubts or fears
examples: The doctor reassured her that the surgery went well
He reassured his children during the thunderstorm
The CEO reassured investors about the company's future
She tried to reassure herself everything would work out

definitions: pay back part of a sum that has been paid
examples: The company rebated customers for the service interruption
They rebated ten percent of the purchase price
The government rebated taxes to low-income families
Manufacturers often rebate dealers for promotional activities

definitions: fight against or resist an established government or ruler
show opposition to accepted rules standards or conventions
examples: The colonists rebelled against British rule in 1776
The army rebelled against the dictator's regime
Teenagers often rebel against their parents' rules
She rebelled against society's expectations for women

definitions: shut down and restart a computer system or device
start something again with significant changes or improvements
examples: You should reboot your computer after installing updates
The server needs to reboot to apply the changes
The studio decided to reboot the film franchise
They're trying to reboot their relationship after counseling

definitions: bounce back after hitting a surface or obstacle
recover in value health or success after a decline
examples: The ball rebounded off the wall with great force
The basketball rebounded high off the rim
Stock prices rebounded after the initial market panic
She rebounded quickly from her illness last month

definitions: transmit a television or radio program again at a later time
examples: The network will rebroadcast the documentary next week
They rebroadcast the game for viewers in different time zones
The speech was rebroadcast on several radio stations
Cable channels often rebroadcast old television series

definitions: construct something again that has been damaged or destroyed
restore or reorganize something to a better condition
examples: They rebuilt their house after the hurricane
The city rebuilt the bridge using modern materials
She slowly rebuilt her life after the divorce
The coach is rebuilding the team with younger players

definitions: express sharp disapproval or criticism of someone's behavior or actions
examples: The teacher rebuked the student for cheating on the test
The judge rebuked the lawyer for unprofessional conduct
She rebuked him publicly for his insensitive comments
The committee rebuked the member for violating protocol

definitions: prove a statement or criticism to be false with evidence or argument
examples: The lawyer rebutted the prosecution's claims with new evidence
Scientists rebutted the theory with experimental data
She carefully rebutted each point in his argument
The report rebuts common misconceptions about climate change

definitions: bring a fact event or experience back into one's mind
officially order someone or something to return from where sent
examples: She couldn't recall where she left her keys
He recalled meeting her at the conference last year
The manufacturer recalled thousands of defective products
The ambassador was recalled to discuss the crisis

definitions: formally withdraw or disavow a previously held belief or statement
examples: The witness recanted his testimony under pressure
Galileo was forced to recant his scientific theories
She refused to recant her political beliefs
The prisoner recanted his confession claiming coercion

definitions: give a summary of the main points of something
examples: Let me recap what we discussed in today's meeting
The host recapped the previous episode's events
She quickly recapped the key findings of the research
Can you recap the main arguments for me?

definitions: catch or take prisoner again after escape or loss
regain or experience again a past feeling or situation
examples: Police recaptured the escaped prisoner within hours
The army recaptured the strategic hill from enemy forces
She tried to recapture the magic of their first date
The band hopes to recapture their early success

definitions: shape metal or other material again in a mold
present something in a different form or style
examples: The foundry recast the damaged bell using the original mold
They had to recast the bronze statue after finding flaws
The director recast the story as a modern drama
She recast her argument to make it more persuasive

definitions: move back or further away from a previous position
gradually diminish in strength amount or intensity
examples: The floodwaters slowly receded after the storm
His hairline has receded significantly over the years
The pain receded after she took the medication
Memories of the accident gradually receded with time

definitions: mark or stamp a bill or document as having been paid or received
examples: Please receipt this invoice to confirm payment
The clerk receipted all incoming packages
The warehouse receipted the delivery at noon
You need to receipt these documents for our records

definitions: be given presented with or paid something from someone
greet or welcome visitors or guests in a formal manner
detect or pick up broadcast signals through electronic equipment
examples: She received a letter from her grandmother yesterday
The charity received donations from many generous people
The ambassador received guests at the embassy reception
The queen receives foreign dignitaries every month
Can you receive this radio station clearly?
The antenna receives signals from the satellite

definitions: restore electrical power to a battery or device by connecting to power
rest and relax to regain energy and enthusiasm
examples: Remember to recharge your phone before the trip
The electric car needs to recharge for three hours
She took a vacation to recharge after the busy season
I need to recharge my batteries this weekend

definitions: respond to a gesture or action with a corresponding one
move backward and forward in a straight line alternately
examples: She reciprocated his feelings of affection
If someone helps you, try to reciprocate the favor
The piston reciprocates inside the cylinder engine
The saw blade reciprocates to cut through wood

definitions: repeat aloud or declaim from memory before an audience
state or list a series of facts or details
examples: The students recited poetry at the school assembly
She recited the pledge of allegiance every morning
The lawyer recited the facts of the case
He recited a long list of complaints

definitions: establish by counting or calculation the number or amount
have an opinion or belief about something
examples: The accountant reckoned the total cost of damages
They reckoned the distance at about fifty miles
I reckon we should leave before the storm
Most experts reckon the economy will improve

definitions: retrieve or recover something previously lost given or stolen
make land suitable for use by draining or irrigating
examples: She reclaimed her luggage from the airport
The museum reclaimed stolen artifacts from collectors
The Dutch reclaimed land from the sea
Farmers reclaimed the desert through irrigation

definitions: identify someone or something from having encountered them before
acknowledge the existence validity or legality of something
show official appreciation for achievement or service
examples: I didn't recognise her with her new hairstyle
The software can recognise faces in photographs
The government recognised the new republic immediately
We must recognise the seriousness of this problem
The company recognised her contributions with an award
His bravery was recognised with a medal

definitions: identify someone or something from having encountered them before
acknowledge the existence validity or legality of something
show official appreciation for achievement or service
examples: I didn't recognize her with her new hairstyle
The software can recognize faces in photographs
The government recognized the new republic immediately
We must recognize the seriousness of this problem
The company recognized her contributions with an award
His bravery was recognized with a medal

definitions: spring or jerk back suddenly in fear or disgust
feel intense disgust or fear at something
examples: She recoiled when she saw the snake
The gun recoiled sharply when he fired it
He recoiled at the thought of eating insects
Most people recoil from extreme violence

definitions: remember or bring back to mind something from the past
examples: She couldn't recollect where she had met him
He tried to recollect the events of that night
I vaguely recollect hearing about this before
Can you recollect what time they arrived?

definitions: combine things again in a different way or after separation
examples: Scientists recombined DNA sequences to create new proteins
The atoms recombine to form different molecules
The company recombined its divisions for better efficiency
Artists often recombine familiar elements in new ways

definitions: put forward someone or something as being good or suitable
advise or suggest a particular course of action
examples: I highly recommend this restaurant for dinner
The committee recommended her for the position
Doctors recommend drinking eight glasses of water daily
The report recommends immediate action on climate change

definitions: make amends to someone for loss or harm suffered
examples: The company recompensed workers for their overtime hours
Insurance will recompense you for the damaged property
Nothing can recompense the family for their loss
The court ordered him to recompense the victims

definitions: restore friendly relations between people after a disagreement
make two or more things compatible or consistent with each other
examples: The couple reconciled after months of separation
The mediator helped reconcile the feuding neighbors
It's hard to reconcile these contradictory statements
She reconciled the bank statements with the receipts

definitions: conquer again territory that was previously held but lost
examples: The empire reconquered the rebellious provinces
Spain reconquered territories from the Moors
The team hopes to reconquer the championship title
They reconquered the market after initial setbacks

definitions: think again about a decision or opinion with possible change
examples: Please reconsider your decision to resign
The board will reconsider the proposal next month
She asked him to reconsider their relationship
You should reconsider before making such a big purchase

definitions: restore something dried to its original state by adding water
reorganize or re-establish something in a different form
examples: Add water to reconstitute the powdered milk
The freeze-dried food reconstitutes quickly with hot water
The committee was reconstituted with new members
They reconstituted the company after bankruptcy

definitions: build or form something again that has been damaged or destroyed
form an impression or model of a past event from evidence
examples: Engineers reconstructed the bridge after the earthquake
Surgeons reconstructed her face after the accident
Police reconstructed the crime from witness statements
Archaeologists reconstructed ancient pottery from fragments

definitions: set down in writing or other permanent form for later reference
achieve a particular measurement or result in a performance
examples: The secretary recorded the minutes of the meeting
Scientists record their observations in detailed notebooks
The thermometer recorded temperatures above forty degrees
She recorded her fastest time in the marathon

definitions: tell someone about something giving all the details or facts
count something again especially votes in an election
examples: She recounted her adventures during the trip
The witness recounted exactly what he had seen
Officials recounted the ballots after complaints
They had to recount all the votes by hand

definitions: regain money or losses through subsequent profits or compensation
examples: The investor hopes to recoup his losses this year
They recouped their investment within six months
Insurance helped them recoup the cost of damages
The company needs to recoup development expenses

definitions: return to a normal state of health mind or strength
find or regain possession of something stolen or lost
extract usable substances or energy from waste or materials
examples: She recovered quickly from the surgery
The economy is recovering from the recession
Police recovered the stolen paintings from a warehouse
He never recovered the money he had lent
The plant recovers silver from photographic waste
We can recover energy from burning waste materials
